page.title: 08DANES DYKE, FLAMBOROUGH
page.content: Danes Dyke is an earthwork believed to have been constructed by Stone Age or Bronze Age men. It consists of a ditch 60ft wide and a bank 18ft high on the eastern side. The Dyke is one of the landing places of the Vikings. Today one side is unspoilt woodland containing deer, foxes, badgers and other wild creatures. The part to the south of the main by road is pre-glacial valley where steep sides are covered with deciduous trees planted as part of the gardens of a large house, since demolished. It is now a nature trail and leisure area. There is a car park, shop and toilets. There is also a big patch of grass where you can play ball games. There is also a picnic area. A steep path leads down to the beach. Danes Dyke is supposed to be haunted by a ghost at midnight called the 'White Lady'.
